qas.question: What type of philosophy does both Kasmir Shaivism and Advaita Vedanta share?
What aspect do non-dual philosophies give to the highest order of worship?
As what does Kashmir Shaivism view the conscious world?
Which group sees the world as illusion?
According to Kashmir Shaivism, what is the goal in belief?
What is the opposite of Shiva?
What are the means of understanding maya according to Kashmir Shaivism?
Advaita says all things are a manifestation of what?

plausible_answers.text: to merge in Shiva or Universal Consciousness

qas.question: What do believers of Advaita believe is the point of human life?

context: Even though, both <b5_0>Kashmir Shaivism and Advaita Vedanta<b5_0/> are <a0_0>non-dual<a0_0/> philosophies which give primacy to <a1_0>Universal Consciousness<a1_0/> (Chit or Brahman), in Kashmir Shavisim, as opposed to Advaita, all things are a manifestation of this <b8_0>Consciousness<b8_0/>. This implies that from the point of view of Kashmir Shavisim, the phenomenal world (Śakti) is <a2_0>real<a2_0/>, and it exists and has its being in Consciousness (Chit). Whereas, <a3_0>Advaita<a3_0/> holds that Brahman is inactive (niṣkriya) and the phenomenal world is an illusion (māyā). The objective of human life, according to Kashmir Shaivism, is <b9_0>to <a4_0>merge in Shiva<a4_0/> or <b6_0>Universal Consciousness<b9_0/><b6_0/>, or to realize one's already existing identity with Shiva, by means of <b7_0>wisdom, yoga and grace<b7_0/>.
